trans-unit.id: Imagine light as a superposition of many individual waves that have different wavelengths (a wavelength is the distance over which the wave’s pattern repeats). For the light visible by human eyes, each wavelength can be associated with a colour. Have you ever tried illuminating a prism with a lamp? You obtain a beautiful rainbow, which is revealing the decomposition of the visible light into its single colours (or single wavelengths). For a human eye, the visible range of wavelength lies between 400 and 700 nanometres (0.000000001 metres). We can see 400 nm as blue, and 700 nm as red. But there are more wavelengths that our eyes cannot see: some shorter than blue, and some longer than red.
trans-unit.source: Imagine light as a superposition of many individual waves that have different wavelengths (a wavelength is the distance over which the wave’s pattern repeats). For the light visible by human eyes, each wavelength can be associated with a colour. Have you ever tried illuminating a prism with a lamp? You obtain a beautiful rainbow, which is revealing the decomposition of the visible light into its single colours (or single wavelengths). For a human eye, the visible range of wavelength lies between 400 and 700 nanometres (0.000000001 metres). We can see 400 nm as blue, and 700 nm as red. But there are more wavelengths that our eyes cannot see: some shorter than blue, and some longer than red.
trans-unit.target: Imagine a luz como uma sobreposição de muitas ondas individuais que têm diferentes comprimentos de onda (o comprimento de onda é a distância a que o padrão da onda se repete). Para a luz visível aos olhos humanos, cada comprimento de onda pode ser associado a uma cor. Já experimentou iluminar um prisma com uma lâmpada? Obtém-se um lindo arco-íris, que revela a decomposição da luz visível nas cores individuais (ou comprimentos de onda individuais). Para o olho humano, o intervalo de comprimentos de onda visíveis vai de 400 a 700 nanometros (1 nm = 0,000000001 m). Vemos os 400 nm como azul e os 700 nm como vermelho. Mas há mais comprimentos de onda que os nosso olhos não conseguem ver: alguns mais curtos que o azul, outros mais longos que o vermelho.

trans-unit.id: Light also carries energy, and the amount of energy depends on the wavelength: the shorter the wavelength, the more energetic the light beam is. Take short wavelength UV light for example: a little is good for the tan, but too much can cause sunburns! Conversely, longer wavelengths are associated with weaker energies. FM radio emissions for example, are harmless to us. In the Universe at large, energetic phenomenon like supernovae emits lots of X-Rays and Gamma Ray which are even more energetic than UV. But the cold gas lying in between stars, or some cold dust particles for example, emit low energy radiations at long wavelengths that fall into the Radio domain.
trans-unit.source: Light also carries energy, and the amount of energy depends on the wavelength: the shorter the wavelength, the more energetic the light beam is. Take short wavelength UV light for example: a little is good for the tan, but too much can cause sunburns! Conversely, longer wavelengths are associated with weaker energies. FM radio emissions for example, are harmless to us. In the Universe at large, energetic phenomenon like supernovae emits lots of X-Rays and Gamma Ray which are even more energetic than UV. But the cold gas lying in between stars, or some cold dust particles for example, emit low energy radiations at long wavelengths that fall into the Radio domain.
trans-unit.target: A luz também carrega energia e a quantidade de energia depende do comprimento de onda: quanto mais curto o comprimento de onda, mais energia tem o feixe de luz. Por exemplo, o comprimento de onda curto da luz UV: em pouca quantidade, é bom para o bronzeado, mas em demasia, pode provocar queimaduras! Os comprimentos de onda mais longos estão associados a energias mais fracas. Emissões de rádio FM, por exemplo, não nos fazem mal. No Universo, fenómenos energéticos como as supernovas, emitem grandes quantidades de Raios X e Raios Gama, que são ainda mais energéticos que o UV. Mas o gás frio que reside entre as estrelas, ou partículas de poeira fria, por exemplo, emitem radiação de baixa energia de comprimento de onda longo que caem no domínio do Rádio.

trans-unit.id: Why is this gas cold? There are stars everywhere, so shouldn’t it be very hot?! Well, it’s true that a galaxy can contain something like a hundred billion of stars. But the distance between them is huge! For example, Proxima Centauri is the closest star from the Sun. It’s at 4.2 light-years from us. That means 40,000,000,000,000 km! At those kinds of distances, the stars do not heat the gas very much! That’s why astronomers observe the interstellar gas in radio!
trans-unit.source: Why is this gas cold? There are stars everywhere, so shouldn’t it be very hot?! Well, it’s true that a galaxy can contain something like a hundred billion of stars. But the distance between them is huge! For example, Proxima Centauri is the closest star from the Sun. It’s at 4.2 light-years from us. That means 40,000,000,000,000 km! At those kinds of distances, the stars do not heat the gas very much! That’s why astronomers observe the interstellar gas in radio!
trans-unit.target: Porque é frio este gás? Há estrelas em toda a parte, não deveria aquecer o gás? bem, a verdade é que uma galáxia pode conter qualquer coisa como uma centena de milhar de milhões de estrelas. Mas a distância entre as estrelas é enorme! Por exemplo, a estrela mais próxima do Sol é a Proxima Centauri e está a 4,2 anos-luz de nós. Isto é, a 40 000 000 000 000 km! A estas distâncias, as estrelas não aquecem muito o gás! Por isso os astrónomos observam o gás interestelar no rádio!

trans-unit.id: Light can be considered as a wave, and also as a particle. Like a wave, it can create interference patterns, like two water waves hitting each other. But it can also be emitted photon by photon, and the photons can be counted in a receiver! Difficult to imagine? Well, take a cylinder. If you illuminate it on its side, its shadow is a square. But illuminate its face, and its shadow becomes a sphere!
trans-unit.source: Light can be considered as a wave, and also as a particle. Like a wave, it can create interference patterns, like two water waves hitting each other. But it can also be emitted photon by photon, and the photons can be counted in a receiver! Difficult to imagine? Well, take a cylinder. If you illuminate it on its side, its shadow is a square. But illuminate its face, and its shadow becomes a sphere!
trans-unit.target: A luz pode ser considerada uma onda, mas também uma partícula. Como uma onda, pode criar um padrão de interferências, tal como duas ondas de água que chocam. Mas também pode ser emitida fotão a fotão e os fotões podem ser contados por um recetor. Difícil de imaginar? Pensem num cilindro. Se o iluminarmos de lado, a sua sombra é um retângulo. Mas se iluminarmos a sua face, a sua sombra transforma-se num círculo!

trans-unit.id: Did you know?
trans-unit.source: Did you know?
trans-unit.target: Sabia?

trans-unit.id: So radio waves are just a kind of light.
trans-unit.source: So radio waves are just a kind of light.
trans-unit.target: Então as ondas de rádio são simplesmente um tipo de luz.

trans-unit.id: What do we use them for?
trans-unit.source: What do we use them for?
trans-unit.target: Para o que as utilizamos?

trans-unit.id: On Earth, we use radio waves mainly for communication purpose. Why? Because they propagate easily through the atmosphere, and even under water. The radio domain is a wide range of wavelengths, extending from kilometres to millimetres. The way they propagate strongly depends on their wavelength, and we take advantage of these different modes of propagation to create our very complex and diverse communication system:
trans-unit.source: On Earth, we use radio waves mainly for communication purpose. Why? Because they propagate easily through the atmosphere, and even under water. The radio domain is a wide range of wavelengths, extending from kilometres to millimetres. The way they propagate strongly depends on their wavelength, and we take advantage of these different modes of propagation to create our very complex and diverse communication system:
trans-unit.target: Na Terra, usamos as ondas de rádio principalmente nas comunicações. Porquê? Porque propagam-se facilmente através da atmosfera e até debaixo de água. O domínio do rádio é um intervalo largo de comprimentos de onda, que vai desde o quilómetro até ao milímetro. A forma como se propagam depende fortemente do comprimento de onda e aproveitamos estas formas diferentes de propagação para criar o nosso complexo e diverso sistema de comunicações:

trans-unit.id: Kilometre wavelengths propagate through surface waves and follow the curvature of the Earth. With enough emission power, they can reach up to 1000 km. They also propagate under water, that’s why they are often used by submarines. Be careful though, it’s not Sonar! Sonar stands for SOund Navigation And Ranging. It’s a technique that uses sound propagation underwater, not light! Amateur radio operators use decametre wavelengths. These wavelengths are very interesting because they are reflected by the Earth’s ionosphere. This means that an amateur radio signal sent to the sky bounces onto the ionosphere back to Earth, and propagates very far. Sometimes it can even reach the antipodes! Why sometimes? Well the reflection processes depends on the state of the ionosphere. Wavelengths below about a metre propagate directly in straight lines from the emitter, almost like visible light. It’s the domain of FM broadcasting, TV emission, Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, etc. These wavelengths are less affected by the ionosphere, that’s why we need satellites to relay them and send them back to Earth.
trans-unit.source: Kilometre wavelengths propagate through surface waves and follow the curvature of the Earth. With enough emission power, they can reach up to 1000 km. They also propagate under water, that’s why they are often used by submarines. Be careful though, it’s not Sonar! Sonar stands for SOund Navigation And Ranging. It’s a technique that uses sound propagation underwater, not light! Amateur radio operators use decametre wavelengths. These wavelengths are very interesting because they are reflected by the Earth’s ionosphere. This means that an amateur radio signal sent to the sky bounces onto the ionosphere back to Earth, and propagates very far. Sometimes it can even reach the antipodes! Why sometimes? Well the reflection processes depends on the state of the ionosphere. Wavelengths below about a metre propagate directly in straight lines from the emitter, almost like visible light. It’s the domain of FM broadcasting, TV emission, Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, etc. These wavelengths are less affected by the ionosphere, that’s why we need satellites to relay them and send them back to Earth.
trans-unit.target: Comprimentos de onda de quilómetros propagam-se através de ondas de superfície e seguem a curvatura da Terra. Com energia suficiente, podem chegar a 1000 km. Também se propagam debaixo de água e por isso são usadas frequentemente por submarinos. Cuidado que não se trata de um Sonar! Sonar vem de SOund Navigation And Ranging (navegação e localização pelo som). Trata-se de uma técnica que utiliza a propagação do som debaixo de água e não de luz! Os radioamadores utilizam comprimentos de onda do decâmetro. Estes comprimentos de onda são muito interessantes porque são refletidos pela ionosfera da Terra. Isto quer dizer que um sinal de radioamador enviado para o céu é refletido pela ionosfera de volta para a Terra e propaga-se até grandes distâncias. Por vezes até pode alcançar os antípodas! Porque só por vezes? Bem, os processos de reflexão dependem do estado da ionosfera. Comprimentos de onda mais curtos que o metro podem propagar-se diretamente em linha reta a partir do emissor, quase como a luz visível. É o domínio da emissão FM, da emissão de TV, Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, etc. Estes comprimentos de onda são menos afetados pela ionosfera e é por isso que precisamos de satélites para os transmitir de volta para a Terra.

trans-unit.target: ionosfera

trans-unit.id: So radio waves are light, not sound. How come I can listen to my favourite songs with my radio? Well, suppose you want to share a song with your friend, 100m away from you. You could shout it very loudly but it would require a huge amount of energy to be heard, which would most likely result in a sore throat and some angry neighbours… Instead you could use your flashlight, translate it into Morse code and send it to your friend. By doing that, you have solved the problem of energy and distance, but you have lost a lot of information in the process. To keep all the information, you have to code the light you are sending in a specific way, so that your friend can receive and decode it easily. This is called signal processing. Frequency Modulation (FM yes, like in FM radio!) is a kind of signal processing that is very easy and cheap to implement. You just modulate the light signal you are sending (the carrier wave) by varying its instantaneous frequency according to that of your message (your song for example). The signal is sent «modulated», and your radio «demodulates» it back to its original form and transmits it to its speakers, thus converting light back into sound!
trans-unit.source: So radio waves are light, not sound. How come I can listen to my favourite songs with my radio? Well, suppose you want to share a song with your friend, 100m away from you. You could shout it very loudly but it would require a huge amount of energy to be heard, which would most likely result in a sore throat and some angry neighbours… Instead you could use your flashlight, translate it into Morse code and send it to your friend. By doing that, you have solved the problem of energy and distance, but you have lost a lot of information in the process. To keep all the information, you have to code the light you are sending in a specific way, so that your friend can receive and decode it easily. This is called signal processing. Frequency Modulation (FM yes, like in FM radio!) is a kind of signal processing that is very easy and cheap to implement. You just modulate the light signal you are sending (the carrier wave) by varying its instantaneous frequency according to that of your message (your song for example). The signal is sent «modulated», and your radio «demodulates» it back to its original form and transmits it to its speakers, thus converting light back into sound!
trans-unit.target: Então as ondas rádio são luz e não som. Nesse caso, porque ouvimos as nossas músicas favoritas com o rádio? Bem, suponha que quer partilhar uma canção com o seu amigo, a 100 m de distância. Podia gritar muito alto, mas requeria muita energia de forma a ser ouvido por ele; o mais provável era ficar com a garganta arranhada e com vizinhos muito zangados... Ao invés, podia usar a lanterna, traduzir a canção para código Morse e enviá-la ao seu amigo. Ao fazê-lo, resolveu o problema da energia e da distância, mas perdeu muita informação no processo. Para manter toda a informação, tem de codificar a luz que está a enviar de uma forma específica, para que o seu amigo possa recebê-la e descodificá-la facilmente. A este processo chama-se processamento do sinal. Modulação em Frequência (FM - Frequency Modulation) é um tipo de processamento de sinal que é muito fácil e barato de implementar. Só temos de modular o sinal de luz que estamos a enviar (a onda transportadora) variando a sua frequência instantânea segundo a nossa mensagem (a canção, por exemplo). O sinal é enviado "modulado" e o rádio "desmodula-o" de volta à sua forma inicial e transmite-o para as suas colunas, convertendo assim a luz em som!

trans-unit.id: Other signal processing methods are used, like Amplitude Modulation (AM) or Phase Modulation (PM) to transmit information. Wi-Fi, for example, uses a combination of FM and PM.
trans-unit.source: Other signal processing methods are used, like Amplitude Modulation (AM) or Phase Modulation (PM) to transmit information. Wi-Fi, for example, uses a combination of FM and PM.

trans-unit.id: The ionosphere is a layer of electrons and other electrically charged particles in the upper atmosphere. It starts at around 80 km from the ground. At this altitude, the atmosphere is too thin to shield the particles from the Solar radiation. Atoms and molecules are hit directly with very energetic light like UV and X-Ray, and this causes them to break and lose some electrons. Their neutral balance is disturbed and they become electrically charged. The resulting mixture of electrons and charged particles is called plasma, and it is responsible for the reflection power of the ionosphere at decametre wavelengths. During the day, Sunbeams hit the ionosphere and produce a lot of charged particles; the ionosphere becomes unstable and cannot reflect the radio signals very efficiently. But at night, the ionosphere is less perturbed and almost acts as a smooth mirror. This is why amateur radio operators prefer to send their long-distance call during the night!
trans-unit.source: The ionosphere is a layer of electrons and other electrically charged particles in the upper atmosphere. It starts at around 80 km from the ground. At this altitude, the atmosphere is too thin to shield the particles from the Solar radiation. Atoms and molecules are hit directly with very energetic light like UV and X-Ray, and this causes them to break and lose some electrons. Their neutral balance is disturbed and they become electrically charged. The resulting mixture of electrons and charged particles is called plasma, and it is responsible for the reflection power of the ionosphere at decametre wavelengths. During the day, Sunbeams hit the ionosphere and produce a lot of charged particles; the ionosphere becomes unstable and cannot reflect the radio signals very efficiently. But at night, the ionosphere is less perturbed and almost acts as a smooth mirror. This is why amateur radio operators prefer to send their long-distance call during the night!
trans-unit.target: A ionosfera é uma camada de eletrões e de outras partículas eletricamente carregadas na alta atmosfera. Começa a cerca de 80 km do solo. A esta altitude, a atmosfera é demasiado fina para proteger as partículas da radiação solar. Os átomos e moléculas são atingidos diretamente com luz muito energética - raios UV e raios X - que lhes arranca eletrões. O seu balanço neutro é perturbado e tornam-se eletricamente carregados. Como resultado, temos uma mistura de eletrões e partículas carregadas chamada plasma que é responsável pela capacidade de reflexão dos comprimentos de onda do decâmetro da ionosfera. Ao longo do dia, raios solares atingem a ionosfera e produzem muitas partículas carregadas; a ionosfera torna-se instável e não consegue refletir eficientemente os sinais de rádio. Mas durante a noite, a ionosfera não é tão perturbada e atua quase como um espelho. Razão pela qual os radioamadores preferem enviar as suas chamadas de grandes distâncias durante a noite.

trans-unit.id: Frequency Modulation (F.M.)
trans-unit.source: Frequency Modulation (F.M.)
trans-unit.target: Modulação de Frequência (F.M.)

trans-unit.id: What is the ionosphere?
trans-unit.source: What is the ionosphere?
trans-unit.target: O que é a ionosfera?

trans-unit.id: While light can propagate in empty spaces, sound cannot. This is because sound waves need a medium they can vibrate into. You can listen to a piano melody because each time the pianist presses a key, a small hammer hits a string and makes it vibrate. The vibration then propagates into the air, until it reaches a receiver like a human ear for example. The ear is in fact a small vibrating membrane (the ear-drum) connected to small bones that transmits the vibration to our nervous system.
trans-unit.source: While light can propagate in empty spaces, sound cannot. This is because sound waves need a medium they can vibrate into. You can listen to a piano melody because each time the pianist presses a key, a small hammer hits a string and makes it vibrate. The vibration then propagates into the air, until it reaches a receiver like a human ear for example. The ear is in fact a small vibrating membrane (the ear-drum) connected to small bones that transmits the vibration to our nervous system.
trans-unit.target: A luz pode propagar-se no vácuo, mas o som não. Isto porque as ondas sonoras precisam de um meio onde possam vibrar. Podemos ouvir uma melodia do piano porque, de cada vez que o pianista pressiona uma tecla, um pequeno martelo bate numa corda e fá-la vibrar. A vibração propaga-se no ar até alcançar um recetor, como por exemplo, um ouvido humano. O ouvido humano é de facto uma pequena membrana que vibra (o tambor) ligada a pequenos ossos que transmitem a vibração ao nosso sistema nervoso.

trans-unit.id: Light and sound are both waves, but their nature is very different.
trans-unit.source: Light and sound are both waves, but their nature is very different.
trans-unit.target: Luz e som são ondas, embora de natureza muito diferente.

trans-unit.id: Why do astronomers use
trans-unit.source: Why do astronomers use
trans-unit.target: Porque utilizam os astrónomos

trans-unit.id: very big telescopes?
trans-unit.source: very big telescopes?
trans-unit.target: telescópios muito grandes?

trans-unit.id: One crucial parameter when observing the sky is the spatial resolution. The spatial resolution is the smallest detail a telescope can observe. The smaller it is, the more details you will observe on your source. The resolution of a telescope, Θ, is proportional to the wavelength, λ, at which you are observing, and inversely proportional to the diameter of the telescope, Φ. Or simply put: So, the more precision we want, the bigger the telescope must be, especially at high wavelengths. How big? Well, let’s do the maths. Let say I want to see someone standing on the Moon with an optical telescope., and to see him with a bit of detail, I want to make an image of him that has a height of 10 pixels. The man on the Moon is 2m tall. First, let’s calculate his apparent size. The apparent size is the angle δ under which an object of size d is seen at a distance D. Using trigonometric relations, it’s fairly easy to find that sin(δ) = d/D. As δ is very small, this simplifies to δ ≈ d/D.
trans-unit.source: One crucial parameter when observing the sky is the spatial resolution. The spatial resolution is the smallest detail a telescope can observe. The smaller it is, the more details you will observe on your source. The resolution of a telescope, Θ, is proportional to the wavelength, λ, at which you are observing, and inversely proportional to the diameter of the telescope, Φ. Or simply put: So, the more precision we want, the bigger the telescope must be, especially at high wavelengths. How big? Well, let’s do the maths. Let say I want to see someone standing on the Moon with an optical telescope., and to see him with a bit of detail, I want to make an image of him that has a height of 10 pixels. The man on the Moon is 2m tall. First, let’s calculate his apparent size. The apparent size is the angle δ under which an object of size d is seen at a distance D. Using trigonometric relations, it’s fairly easy to find that sin(δ) = d/D. As δ is very small, this simplifies to δ ≈ d/D.
trans-unit.target: Quando se observa o céu, um parâmetro crucial é a resolução espacial. A resolução espacial é o detalhe mais pequeno que um telescópio pode observar. Quanto menor for, mais detalhes podemos ver na nossa fonte. A resolução do telescópio, Θ, é proporcional ao comprimento de onda, λ, a que estamos a observar, e inversamente proporcional ao diâmetro do telescópio, Φ. Ou, simplesmente, quanto mais precisão queremos, maior tem de ser o telescópio, especialmente a grandes comprimentos de onda. Quão grande? Façamos as contas. Pretendemos ver uma pessoa na Lua com um telescópio ótico. Para ver alguns pormenores na pessoa, queremos que a sua imagem tenha uma altura de 10 píxeis. O homem na Lua tem 2 m de altura. Primeiro, calculemos o seu tamanho aparente. O tamanho aparente é o ângulo δ que subentende um objecto de tamanho d visto a uma distância D. Usando relações trigonométricas, é relativamente fácil obter que sen(δ) = d/D. Como δ é muito pequeno, podemos fazer a aproximação δ ≈ d/D.

trans-unit.source: Diameter
trans-unit.target: Diâmetro

trans-unit.id: Here, D is the distance to the Moon, which is hidden somewhere in this poster. If you want to calculate δ be careful that d and D are in the same units! You obtain δ in radian. Now, we said we need 10 pixels to sample our image of the man, so our spatial resolution Θ should be equal to δ/10 Using the formula of the spatial resolution, and the center wavelength of the visible spectrum (it’s probably somewhere on another poster, you will have to look for it – again: be careful with the units!), you can now calculate the diameter of the telescope you will have to build. You have it? Here’s a hint: it’s roughly the width of Central park in New York. It’s also 3 times the height of the Eiffel Tower… This explains why astronomers always thrive for bigger telescopes! And the spatial resolution issue becomes critical at longer wavelengths. For radio observations, the telescopes are gigantic.
trans-unit.source: Here, D is the distance to the Moon, which is hidden somewhere in this poster. If you want to calculate δ be careful that d and D are in the same units! You obtain δ in radian. Now, we said we need 10 pixels to sample our image of the man, so our spatial resolution Θ should be equal to δ/10 Using the formula of the spatial resolution, and the center wavelength of the visible spectrum (it’s probably somewhere on another poster, you will have to look for it – again: be careful with the units!), you can now calculate the diameter of the telescope you will have to build. You have it? Here’s a hint: it’s roughly the width of Central park in New York. It’s also 3 times the height of the Eiffel Tower… This explains why astronomers always thrive for bigger telescopes! And the spatial resolution issue becomes critical at longer wavelengths. For radio observations, the telescopes are gigantic.
trans-unit.target: Aqui, D é a distância à Lua, que está escondida algures neste poster. Se quiser calcular δ tenha cuidado que d e D estão nas mesmas unidades! Obtemos δ em radianos. Como queremos 10 píxeis para a nossa imagem do homem, a nossa resolução espacial Θ deve ser δ/10. Usando a fórmula da resolução espacial e o comprimento de onda central do espetro visível (encontra-se algures noutro poster, terá de procurá-lo - novamente, cuidado com as unidades!), já pode calcular o diâmetro do telescópio que terá de construir. Já tem a resposta? Aqui vai uma pista: é aproximadamente a largura do Central Park, em Nova Iorque. Ou, se preferir, 3 vezes a altura da Torre Eiffel... Percebe-se a permanente necessidade que os astrónomos têm de construir telescópios maiores! E a resolução espacial torna-se crítica a grandes comprimentos de onda. Para observações de rádio, os telescópios são gigantescos.

trans-unit.id: Take for example the Arecibo Observatory: this huge telescope of 305 m diameter is the largest telescope ever built. It is located on the island of Puerto Rico, in the Caribbean. It observes a wide area of centimetre wavelengths. Its impressive size has earned him several appearances in movies, like in the James Bond film: GoldenEye. Another example is the Nançay Radio Telescope in France: Located 2h south of Paris in the Sologne forest near Orleans, this 460 m long radio telescope has two huge mirrors: a plane one of 200x40 m and a spherical one of 300x35 m. Centimetre radio waves are collected by the focal carriage at the centre of the instrument. The plane mirror is movable vertically, only allowing observations of objects passing through the local meridian. It is thus called a meridian instrument.
trans-unit.source: Take for example the Arecibo Observatory: this huge telescope of 305 m diameter is the largest telescope ever built. It is located on the island of Puerto Rico, in the Caribbean. It observes a wide area of centimetre wavelengths. Its impressive size has earned him several appearances in movies, like in the James Bond film: GoldenEye. Another example is the Nançay Radio Telescope in France: Located 2h south of Paris in the Sologne forest near Orleans, this 460 m long radio telescope has two huge mirrors: a plane one of 200x40 m and a spherical one of 300x35 m. Centimetre radio waves are collected by the focal carriage at the centre of the instrument. The plane mirror is movable vertically, only allowing observations of objects passing through the local meridian. It is thus called a meridian instrument.
trans-unit.target: Tomemos por exemplo o Observatório de Arecibo: este telescópio de 305 m de diâmetro é o maior telescópio até agora construído. Encontra-se na ilha de Porto Rico, nas Caraíbas, e realiza observações num intervalo grande de comprimentos de onda do centímetro. O seu tamanho impressionante já o levou a aparecer em vários filmes, como por exemplo, no filme do James Bond, Golden Eye. Outro exemplo é o Radiotelescópio de Nançay, em França, localizado a 2 h a sul de Paris, na floresta de Sologne. Este radiotelescópio de 460 m tem dois grandes espelhos: um espelho plano de 200 m x 40 m e um espelho esférico de 300 m x 35 m. As ondas de rádio do centímetro são recolhidas pelo recetor no centro do instrumento. O espelho plano move-se verticalmente, permitindo apenas observações de objetos que passem pelo meridiano local.

trans-unit.id: A diameter of 305 m is impressive in size, and it’s also a technical challenge to keep the surface of the mirror regular so that the radio signals can converge to the same point. So does that mean that it is the best we could ever do? Well, hopefully we will be able to do even better. One observing technique can overcome this limit: it’s called interferometry.
trans-unit.source: A diameter of 305 m is impressive in size, and it’s also a technical challenge to keep the surface of the mirror regular so that the radio signals can converge to the same point. So does that mean that it is the best we could ever do? Well, hopefully we will be able to do even better. One observing technique can overcome this limit: it’s called interferometry.
trans-unit.target: Um diâmetro de 305 m é impressionante em tamanho, mas é também um desafio técnico de manutenção da superfície do espelho regular de forma a que os sinais de rádio possam convergir sempre para o mesmo ponto.Será que é o melhor que conseguimos fazer? Bem, esperamos conseguir fazer ainda melhor. Uma técnica de observação que pode ultrapassar este limite é a interferometria.

trans-unit.id: the Interferometry Technique
trans-unit.source: the Interferometry Technique

trans-unit.id: Better, stronger, but a bit more difficult!
trans-unit.source: Better, stronger, but a bit more difficult!
trans-unit.target: Melhor, mas um pouco mais difícil!

trans-unit.id: The difficulty in achieving high resolutions with single-dish radio telescopes has led the use of another observing technique: Interferometry. First of all, what is interference? To understand the concept of interference, let’s visualise the light as a wave. If a surface with two small holes in it gets illuminated, it should produce this effect:
trans-unit.source: The difficulty in achieving high resolutions with single-dish radio telescopes has led the use of another observing technique: Interferometry. First of all, what is interference? To understand the concept of interference, let’s visualise the light as a wave. If a surface with two small holes in it gets illuminated, it should produce this effect:
trans-unit.target: A dificuldade em obter altas resoluções com um único radiotelescópio levou ao desenvolvimento de outra técnica de observação: a interferometria. Primeiro que tudo, o que é interferência? Para compreender o conceito de interferência, vamos visualizar a luz como uma onda. Se uma superfície com dois pequenos buracos ficar iluminada, deverá produzir este efeito:

trans-unit.id: Where the two waves coming out the holes overlap, they will add up if they are in phase, or cancel each other when they are out of phase. Something similar to this happen when you push someone on a swing: your friend will gain height only if your movements are in phase with the movements of the swing. With the light experiment depicted above, here is what you can observe on a screen:
trans-unit.source: Where the two waves coming out the holes overlap, they will add up if they are in phase, or cancel each other when they are out of phase. Something similar to this happen when you push someone on a swing: your friend will gain height only if your movements are in phase with the movements of the swing. With the light experiment depicted above, here is what you can observe on a screen:
trans-unit.target: Nos pontos em que as duas ondas que saem dos buracos se sobrepõem, elas vão-se somar se estiverem em fase, ou cancelar-se se estiverem fora de fase. Algo parecido acontece quando empurramos uma criança num baloiço: ela só ganhará altura se os nossos movimentos estiverem em fase com os do baloiço. Com a experiência da luz descrita acima, eis o que podemos observar num écran:

trans-unit.id: Want to do this at home? Well, that’s fairly easy as long as you have a laser pointer and three pieces of pencil lead. Hold the three pieces of lead between your thumb and your index, and try to make them as parallel as possible. Put them in front of your laser pointer, and look at the result on the wall: there you have it! You’ve just created interferences!
trans-unit.source: Want to do this at home? Well, that’s fairly easy as long as you have a laser pointer and three pieces of pencil lead. Hold the three pieces of lead between your thumb and your index, and try to make them as parallel as possible. Put them in front of your laser pointer, and look at the result on the wall: there you have it! You’ve just created interferences!
trans-unit.target: Quer fazer isto em casa? É bastante fácil desde que tenha um apontador laser e três minas para lapiseira. Segure as três minas entre o polegar e o indicador e tente pô-las tão paralelas quanto possível. Coloque-as em frente ao apontador laser e veja o resultado na parede! Acabou de criar interferências!

trans-unit.id: So what happens with an astronomical source in radio waves?
trans-unit.source: So what happens with an astronomical source in radio waves?
trans-unit.target: O que acontece com uma fonte astronómica de ondas rádio?

trans-unit.id: The Plateau de Bure Interferometer: on a plateau in the south of France, near Gap, is a network of six antennas of 15 m in diameter, observing in the millimetre range. They can move on rails and their maximum extension can reach up to 700 m.
trans-unit.source: The Plateau de Bure Interferometer: on a plateau in the south of France, near Gap, is a network of six antennas of 15 m in diameter, observing in the millimetre range. They can move on rails and their maximum extension can reach up to 700 m.
trans-unit.target: O Interferómetro Plateau de Bure: num planalto no sul de França, perto de Gap, encontra-se uma rede de seis antenas de 15 m de diâmetro cada, que observam no milímetro. Podem deslocar-se em carris e a sua extensão máxima pode chegar a 700 m.

trans-unit.id: The Very Large Array: featured in the famous movie Contact. This interferometer is located in the desert plains of New Mexico, near Socorro, and observes in centimetre wavelengths. It’s a network of 27 movable antennas, put together to reach impressive spatial resolutions. Indeed the, array configurations are spanning from 1 km up to 36 km!
trans-unit.source: The Very Large Array: featured in the famous movie Contact. This interferometer is located in the desert plains of New Mexico, near Socorro, and observes in centimetre wavelengths. It’s a network of 27 movable antennas, put together to reach impressive spatial resolutions. Indeed the, array configurations are spanning from 1 km up to 36 km!
trans-unit.target: O Very Large Array: aparece no filme Contacto. Este interferómetro encontra-se nas planícies do deserto do Novo México, perto de Socorro, e observa comprimentos de onda do centímetro. É uma rede de 27 antenas móveis, que trabalhando em conjunto alcançam resoluções espaciais impressionantes. As configurações das antenas pode estender-se desde 1 km até 36 km.

trans-unit.id: In a simple two-element radio interferometer, the signals from source alternately arrive in phase and out of phase as the Earth rotates and causes a change in the difference in path (the “d” on the picture) from the radio source to the two elements of the interferometer. This produces interference fringes in a manner similar to what was shown in the double slit experiment with visible light. If the radio source has finite angular size, then “d” varies across the source. The measured interference fringes from the interferometer pair thus depend on the detailed nature of the radio «brightness» distribution in the sky. For a radio interferometer with several antennas, each pair produces different fringes, and information from the fringes can be used to reconstruct the original image.
trans-unit.source: In a simple two-element radio interferometer, the signals from source alternately arrive in phase and out of phase as the Earth rotates and causes a change in the difference in path (the “d” on the picture) from the radio source to the two elements of the interferometer. This produces interference fringes in a manner similar to what was shown in the double slit experiment with visible light. If the radio source has finite angular size, then “d” varies across the source. The measured interference fringes from the interferometer pair thus depend on the detailed nature of the radio «brightness» distribution in the sky. For a radio interferometer with several antennas, each pair produces different fringes, and information from the fringes can be used to reconstruct the original image.
trans-unit.target: Num interferómetro rádio de dois elementos, os sinais da fonte chegam alternadamente em fase e fora de fase, à medida que a Terra roda e provoca uma alteração no caminho percorrido pelo sinal (o "d" da imagem) desde a fonte de rádio até aos dois elementos do interferómetro. Isto produz franjas de interferência semelhantes às que mostrámos na experiência com a luz visível. Se a fonte de rádio tem um tamanho angular finito, então "d" varia ao longo da fonte. As franjas de interferência medidas depende então da natureza detalhada da distribuição de brilho de rádio no céu. Para um interferómetro de rádio com várias antenas, cada par procuz franjas diferentes e a informação das franjas pode ser usada para reconstruir a imagem original da fonte.

trans-unit.id: The Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) will initially be composed of 66 high-precision antennas working together at millimeter and submillimeter wavelengths, with a possible extension in the future. Thanks to its high resolution and sensitivity, ALMA will bring a new vision of the Universe, allowing scientists to unravel longstanding and important astronomical mysteries.
trans-unit.source: The Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) will initially be composed of 66 high-precision antennas working together at millimeter and submillimeter wavelengths, with a possible extension in the future. Thanks to its high resolution and sensitivity, ALMA will bring a new vision of the Universe, allowing scientists to unravel longstanding and important astronomical mysteries.
trans-unit.target: O Atacama Large Milimeter Array (ALMA) será inicialmente composto por 66 antenas de alta precisão que trabalharão juntas no domínio dos comprimentos de onda do milímetro e submilímetro, mas poderá ainda crescer mais no futuro. Graças à sua alta resolução e sensibilidade, o ALMA trará uma nova visão do Universo, permitindo que os cientistas desvendem mistérios de longa data.

trans-unit.id: Now you know how to reconstruct an image from interference patterns. But what’s the point of all this? It’s a very important point: in interferometry, the spatial resolution is not calculated from the diameter of the telescopes, but from the longest distance between a pair of telescopes! This means that an interferometer with telescopes distant from 1 km can obtain an image as if it was taken by a single-dish telescope of this diameter!
trans-unit.source: Now you know how to reconstruct an image from interference patterns. But what’s the point of all this? It’s a very important point: in interferometry, the spatial resolution is not calculated from the diameter of the telescopes, but from the longest distance between a pair of telescopes! This means that an interferometer with telescopes distant from 1 km can obtain an image as if it was taken by a single-dish telescope of this diameter!
trans-unit.target: Agora já sabe reconstruir uma imagem a partir de padrões de interferência. Mas qual é o objetivo? Em interferometria, a resolução espacial não é calculada a partir do diâmetro dos telescópios, mas sim a partir da maior distância entre um par de telescópios! Isto quer dizer que um interferómetro com telescópios que distem 1 km entre si podem obter uma imagem com o se fosse um único telescópio desse diâmetro!

trans-unit.id: In recognition of their contributions to the development of radio interferometry using the earth-rotation synthesis, two British Astronomers Martin Ryle and Antony Hewish were awarded the 1974 Nobel Prize for Physics.
trans-unit.source: In recognition of their contributions to the development of radio interferometry using the earth-rotation synthesis, two British Astronomers Martin Ryle and Antony Hewish were awarded the 1974 Nobel Prize for Physics.
trans-unit.target: Em reconhecimento das suas contribuições para o desenvolvimento da interferometria de rádio usando a rotação de Terra, dois astrónomos britânicos, Martin Ryle e Antony Hewish foram agraciados com o Prémio Nóbel da Física em 1974.

trans-unit.id: From the Sky to the Computer:
trans-unit.source: From the Sky to the Computer:
trans-unit.target: Do Céu até ao Computador:

trans-unit.id: What is the receiver made of? As we are going to tackle the technical aspect of radio observations, we should adapt a bit our vocabulary. It will be more practical to talk about frequencies instead of wavelengths, because hardware sample the incoming signal at a certain frequency rate. If the radio signal is expressed in frequency too, it’s more convenient to compare them to each other. And switching from wavelength λ to frequency υ, is easy: we use this simple relation υ=c/λ (where c is the speed of light) In a simple chain of acquisition, the first element that collects the radio signal is a small antenna, which can take several forms depending on the wavelength. For short radio wavelengths, millimetres for example, the antenna is a corrugated horn, plugged to a waveguide. For longer wavelengths like centimetre, a simple copper wire is enough.
trans-unit.source: What is the receiver made of? As we are going to tackle the technical aspect of radio observations, we should adapt a bit our vocabulary. It will be more practical to talk about frequencies instead of wavelengths, because hardware sample the incoming signal at a certain frequency rate. If the radio signal is expressed in frequency too, it’s more convenient to compare them to each other. And switching from wavelength λ to frequency υ, is easy: we use this simple relation υ=c/λ (where c is the speed of light) In a simple chain of acquisition, the first element that collects the radio signal is a small antenna, which can take several forms depending on the wavelength. For short radio wavelengths, millimetres for example, the antenna is a corrugated horn, plugged to a waveguide. For longer wavelengths like centimetre, a simple copper wire is enough.
trans-unit.target: De que é feito o recetor? Já que vamos abordar o aspeto técnico das observações de rádio, devemos adaptar o nosso vocabulário para o efeito. É mais prático falar sobre frequências em vez de comprimentos de onda, pois o hardware analisa o sinal de entrada a um certo varrimento de frequência. Se o sinal de rádio também for expresso em frequência, a comparação entre eles torna-se mais direta. A consversão de comprimento de onda λ em frequência υ é fácil: usamos esta relação υ=c/λ (oinde c é a velocidade da luz). Num simples cadeia de aquisição, o primeiro elemento que recolhe o sinal de rádio é a pequena antena, que pode ter diferentes formas dependendo do comprimento de onda a que trabalha. Para comprimentos de onda pequenos , por exemplo, do milímetro, a antena é um corrugated horn, ligada a um guia de onda. Para comprimentos de onda maiores, como o centímetro, um simples fio de cobre é suficiente.

trans-unit.id: the Hitchhiker’s Guide to the radio Universe
trans-unit.source: the Hitchhiker’s Guide to the radio Universe
trans-unit.target: o Guia do Universo de Rádio do Pendura

trans-unit.id: As you can see from the picture, the atmosphere is transparent for a large part of the radio domain. This means that observations are possible in daylight! Think about the poor radio astronomers who never get to sleep…
trans-unit.source: As you can see from the picture, the atmosphere is transparent for a large part of the radio domain. This means that observations are possible in daylight! Think about the poor radio astronomers who never get to sleep…
trans-unit.target: Como pode ver pela imagem, a atmosfera da Terra é transparente para grande parte do domínio de rádio. Isto quer dizer que as observações são possíveis durante o dia! Pense nos pobres radioastrónomos que nunca se deitam...

trans-unit.id: Atmospheric opacity
trans-unit.source: Atmospheric opacity
trans-unit.target: Opacidade atmosférica

trans-unit.id: The signal is collected with the primary reflector of the telescope. It usually has the shape of a parabola, though it could also be spherical. The important property of this primary reflector is that it converges the signal to a single point, called the focal point. At the focal point, there can be the receiver itself, or another mirror called the sub-reflector that relays the signal to the receiver.
trans-unit.source: The signal is collected with the primary reflector of the telescope. It usually has the shape of a parabola, though it could also be spherical. The important property of this primary reflector is that it converges the signal to a single point, called the focal point. At the focal point, there can be the receiver itself, or another mirror called the sub-reflector that relays the signal to the receiver.
trans-unit.target: O sinal é recolhido com o refletor primário do telescópio. Normalmente, tem a forma de uma parábola, embora também possa ser esférico. A propriedade mais importante deste refletor primário é que converge o sinal para um único ponto, chamado ponto focal. No ponto focal, podemos encontrar o recetor propriamente dito, ou outro espelho chamado sub-refletor que reflete o sinal para o recetor.

trans-unit.id: Copper wire for centimetre wavelengths reception.
trans-unit.source: Copper wire for centimetre wavelengths reception.

trans-unit.id: The small antenna is then linked to a filter that selects the range of frequencies around the frequency of interest. A high frequency amplifier boosts the resulting signal. Once amplified, the trick is to convert the analog signal (a smoothly variating voltage) to a digital signal (an encoded version). But the source frequencies are too high to be sampled with any ordinary hardware! The sample rate is just too high, even an expensive state-of-the-art analog to digital converter could not do it… But here is a simple solution: why not shift the frequency to a much lower one, so that it can be analysed?! Well, this is called heterodyne detection, and it is a technique that is frequently used in radio reception, not only in astronomy, but also in communication.
trans-unit.source: The small antenna is then linked to a filter that selects the range of frequencies around the frequency of interest. A high frequency amplifier boosts the resulting signal. Once amplified, the trick is to convert the analog signal (a smoothly variating voltage) to a digital signal (an encoded version). But the source frequencies are too high to be sampled with any ordinary hardware! The sample rate is just too high, even an expensive state-of-the-art analog to digital converter could not do it… But here is a simple solution: why not shift the frequency to a much lower one, so that it can be analysed?! Well, this is called heterodyne detection, and it is a technique that is frequently used in radio reception, not only in astronomy, but also in communication.
trans-unit.target: A pequena antena é ligada a um filtro que seleciona o intervalo de frequências centrado na frequência de interesse. Um amplificador de alta frequência aumenta o sinal resultante. Uma vez amplificado, o truque é converter o sinal analógico (uma suave variação de voltagem) num sinal digital (uma versão codificada). Mas as frequências da fonte são demasiado elevadas para serem decompostas individualmente por um equipamento normal, pois seria necessário um poder de resolução muito elevado. Mas há uma solução simples: porque não desviar a frequência para uma muito menor de forma a poder ser analisada? Isto chama-se deteção heterodina e é uma técnica usada frequentemente na receção de rádio, não só na astronomia, mas também nas comunicações.

trans-unit.id: In heterodyne detection, the signal is mixed with a known signal, generated locally by a stable laser. It is called the Local Oscillator. The Local Oscillator has a frequency (FLO) close to that of the sky signal (FSKY), and it can be tuned so that the difference between FLO and FSKY is equal to a fixed frequency that is called the Intermediate Frequency. To put it simply: F SKY - F LO = F Intermediate The Intermediate Frequency is just the right frequency to be sampled by cheaper hardware, less difficult to build and more reliable. Once converted into bits, the signal can be analysed by software and shifted back to the real observed frequency just by numerically adding back again FLO.
trans-unit.source: In heterodyne detection, the signal is mixed with a known signal, generated locally by a stable laser. It is called the Local Oscillator. The Local Oscillator has a frequency (FLO) close to that of the sky signal (FSKY), and it can be tuned so that the difference between FLO and FSKY is equal to a fixed frequency that is called the Intermediate Frequency. To put it simply: F SKY - F LO = F Intermediate The Intermediate Frequency is just the right frequency to be sampled by cheaper hardware, less difficult to build and more reliable. Once converted into bits, the signal can be analysed by software and shifted back to the real observed frequency just by numerically adding back again FLO.
trans-unit.target: Na deteção heterodina, o sinal é misturado com um sinal conhecido, gerado localmente por um laser estável. É chamado Oscilador Local. O Oscilador Local tem uma frequência (FLO) próxima da do sinal do céu (FSKY) e pode ser ajustada de forma a que a diferença entre FLO e FSKY seja igual a uma frequência fixa, a chamada Frequência Intermédia. A Frequência Intermédia é simplesmente a frequência certa para ser decomposta por equipamento normal. Uma vez convertida em bits, o sinal pode ser analisado pelo software e desviado para a frequência observada, simplesmente adicionando FLO.

trans-unit.id: Now that we have our signal in a computer, let’s do some science!
trans-unit.source: Now that we have our signal in a computer, let’s do some science!
trans-unit.target: Agora que temos o nosso sinal num computador, vamos fazer ciência!

trans-unit.id: A simplified schematic of the heterodyne detection process.
trans-unit.source: A simplified schematic of the heterodyne detection process.
trans-unit.target: Um esquema simplificado do processo de deteção heterodina.

trans-unit.id: Radio Sources of the Universe
trans-unit.source: Radio Sources of the Universe
trans-unit.target: Fontes de Rádio do Universo

trans-unit.id: What are we receiving from the sky?
trans-unit.source: What are we receiving from the sky?
trans-unit.target: O que estamos a receber do céu?

trans-unit.id: The Sun is one of the closest astronomical radio sources. Most of its radio emission comes from its corona, a layer above the photosphere where there are a lot of charged particles forming what is called plasma. Radio emission can also arise from magnetic storms, which form spots on its surface.
trans-unit.source: The Sun is one of the closest astronomical radio sources. Most of its radio emission comes from its corona, a layer above the photosphere where there are a lot of charged particles forming what is called plasma. Radio emission can also arise from magnetic storms, which form spots on its surface.
trans-unit.target: O Sol é uma das fontes de rádio mais próximas de nós. A maior parte da sua emissão de rádio vem da coroa, uma camada acima da fotosfera onde existem muitas partículas carregadas que formam um plasma. As tempestades magnéticas também dão origem a emissão de rádio, que formam manchas na sua superfície.

trans-unit.id: Pulsars the radio lighthouses of the Universe. Like a spinning top, a pulsar is rotating along itself continuously. The radio beams emitted by the pulsar follow its rotation, like a lighthouse on a sea shore. They are received on Earth as short signals (“bip bip bip”). Nearly 2000 pulsars have been observed in our Galaxy and billions exists in the whole Universe.
trans-unit.source: Pulsars the radio lighthouses of the Universe. Like a spinning top, a pulsar is rotating along itself continuously. The radio beams emitted by the pulsar follow its rotation, like a lighthouse on a sea shore. They are received on Earth as short signals (“bip bip bip”). Nearly 2000 pulsars have been observed in our Galaxy and billions exists in the whole Universe.
trans-unit.target: Pulsares: os faróis de rádio do Universo. Tal como um pião a girar, um pulsar roda sobre si mesmo continuamente. Os feixes de rádio que o pulsar emite seguem a sua rotação, tal como um farol na costa. São recebidos na Terra como sinais curtos (“bip bip bip”). Quase 2000 pulsares foram observados na nossa Galáxia e há milhares de milhões em todo o Universo.

trans-unit.id: The pulsar lighthouse effect
trans-unit.source: The pulsar lighthouse effect
trans-unit.target: O efeito de farol do pulsar

trans-unit.id: Galaxies are made of cold gas that emits energy in the radio domain. In some galaxies, the centre is buried deep inside lots of dust clouds that shield the visible light from us, but radio waves can pierce through the cloud and can be observed. They are called “radio galaxies”.
trans-unit.source: Galaxies are made of cold gas that emits energy in the radio domain. In some galaxies, the centre is buried deep inside lots of dust clouds that shield the visible light from us, but radio waves can pierce through the cloud and can be observed. They are called “radio galaxies”.
trans-unit.target: As galáxias são feitas de gás frio que emite energia no domínio do rádio. Em algumas galáxias, o centro está enterrado em nuvens de poeira que escondem a luz visível de nós. Mas as ondas rádio podem perfurar as nuvens de poeira e podemos observar estas galáxias neste comprimento de onda. São as chamadas rádiogaláxias.

trans-unit.id: False-colour image of the nearby radiogalaxy Centaurus A, showing radio (red), infrared (green) and X-ray emission (blue).
trans-unit.source: False-colour image of the nearby radiogalaxy Centaurus A, showing radio (red), infrared (green) and X-ray emission (blue).
trans-unit.target: Imagem em falsa cor de uma radiogaláxia próxima, Centaurus A, mostrando a emissão rádio (vermelho), a emissão infravermelha (verde) e a emissão de raios X (azul).

trans-unit.id: The Cosmic Microwave Background cosmological models predicted that if the Universe originates from a Big Bang, there should be a leftover radiation. It was first discovered in 1964 by American radio astronomers Arno Penzias and Robert Wilson. They were the first to bring a solid observational proof to the Big Bang Theory, and this earned them the 1978 Nobel Prize.
trans-unit.source: The Cosmic Microwave Background cosmological models predicted that if the Universe originates from a Big Bang, there should be a leftover radiation. It was first discovered in 1964 by American radio astronomers Arno Penzias and Robert Wilson. They were the first to bring a solid observational proof to the Big Bang Theory, and this earned them the 1978 Nobel Prize.
trans-unit.target: O Fundo Cósmico de Micro-ondas Os modelos cosmológicos previam que se o Universo tivesse tido origem no Bib Bang, deveria ainda existir radiação que restou do início. Foi descoberta pela primeira vez em 1964 pelos radioastrónomos Arno Penzias and Robert Wilson (EUA). Foram os primeiros a trazer uma prova sólida observacional da Teoria do Big Bang, o que os fez ganhar o Prémio Nobel em 1978.

trans-unit.id: In 1054 BC, the Chinese people were able to observe a bright new star in the sky: it was a supernova explosion. A millennium later, we can observe a beautiful nebula in the same place: the Crab nebula. At its very centre lies a peculiar star: a pulsar.
trans-unit.source: In 1054 BC, the Chinese people were able to observe a bright new star in the sky: it was a supernova explosion. A millennium later, we can observe a beautiful nebula in the same place: the Crab nebula. At its very centre lies a peculiar star: a pulsar.
trans-unit.target: Em 1054 a.C. o povo chinês teve a oportunidade de observar um estrela nova no céu, muito brilhante: era uma explosão de supernova! Mil anos depois, nós observamos uma nebulosa maravilhosa no mesmo local: a nebulosa do Caranguejo. No seu centro encontra-se uma estrela peculiar: um pulsar.

trans-unit.id: what information brings a radio signal?
trans-unit.source: what information brings a radio signal?
trans-unit.target: que informação nos trás um sinal de rádio?

trans-unit.id: What information can we deduce from radio observations? As you should know by now, the spatial resolution of a radio telescope is not that great, unless it’s a huge telescope of 300 m of diameter or an interferometer. For example, a 3m telescope like the one of the EU-HOU project has a resolution of 5°. It’s ten times the angular size of the Sun! So, no image? Not with a 3m telescope, no. But with an interferometer, like the Plateau de Bure Interferometer for example, you can make some beautiful pictures like this one for example: It traces the molecular content of a nearby galaxy called the Whirlpool galaxy. Remember, your eyes cannot see radio emission, so astronomers used this colour scale is here to help us: blue is not very intense, and red is the most intense. That means that when it’s the reddest, there are a lot of molecules in there!
trans-unit.source: What information can we deduce from radio observations? As you should know by now, the spatial resolution of a radio telescope is not that great, unless it’s a huge telescope of 300 m of diameter or an interferometer. For example, a 3m telescope like the one of the EU-HOU project has a resolution of 5°. It’s ten times the angular size of the Sun! So, no image? Not with a 3m telescope, no. But with an interferometer, like the Plateau de Bure Interferometer for example, you can make some beautiful pictures like this one for example: It traces the molecular content of a nearby galaxy called the Whirlpool galaxy. Remember, your eyes cannot see radio emission, so astronomers used this colour scale is here to help us: blue is not very intense, and red is the most intense. That means that when it’s the reddest, there are a lot of molecules in there!
trans-unit.target: Que informação podemos deduzir das observações de rádio? Como já se deve ter apercebido, a resolução espacial de um radiotelescópio não é muito boa, a não ser que seja um telescópio de 300 m de diâmetro, ou um interferómetro. Por exemplo, um telescópio de 3 m como o do projeto EU-HOU tem uma resolução de 5º. É dez vezes o tamanho angular do Sol! Quer isso dizer que não há imagem? Com um telescópio de 3 m, de facto, não há imagem. Mas com o interferómetro como o de Plateau de Bure, por exemplo, pode-se fazer imagens lindas como esta por exemplo: está a It traces the molecular content of a nearby galaxy called the Whirlpool galaxy. Remember, your eyes cannot see radio emission, so astronomers used this colour scale is here to help us: blue is not very intense, and red is the most intense. That means that when it’s the reddest, there are a lot of molecules in there!

trans-unit.id: So, no chance to retrieve anything interesting with my 3m radio telescope, then? Yes! Spatial information is not the only thing an astronomer longs for. For example, radio astronomy offers a very interesting physical property: the velocity of what you observe. How?
trans-unit.source: So, no chance to retrieve anything interesting with my 3m radio telescope, then? Yes! Spatial information is not the only thing an astronomer longs for. For example, radio astronomy offers a very interesting physical property: the velocity of what you observe. How?
trans-unit.target: Então não obtemos nada interessante com uma radioantena de 3 m? Claro que sim! A informação espacial não é a única informação que os astrónomos querem. Por exemplo, em radioastronomia obtemos uma propriedade física muito interessante: a velocidade do que observamos. Como?

trans-unit.id: Thanks to the Doppler effect! The Doppler effect is the change in wavelength of a wave for an observer moving relative to its source. You can experience the Doppler effect when a vehicle sounding a siren or horn approaches, passes, and recedes from you. It’s this niiiiiiiiuuuuuuuuuum sound! The light, as it’s a wave like the sound, behave the same way:
trans-unit.source: Thanks to the Doppler effect! The Doppler effect is the change in wavelength of a wave for an observer moving relative to its source. You can experience the Doppler effect when a vehicle sounding a siren or horn approaches, passes, and recedes from you. It’s this niiiiiiiiuuuuuuuuuum sound! The light, as it’s a wave like the sound, behave the same way:
trans-unit.target: Graças ao efeito de Doppler! O efeito de Doppler é a alteração no comprimento de onda de uma onda para um observador que se move relativamente à fonte das ondas. Deparamo-nos com o efeito de Doppler quando uma ambulância com a sirene ligada aproxima-se, passa e afasta-se de nós. É o niiiiiiiiuuuuuuuuuum que se ouve! A luz, tal como o som, é uma onda e comporta-se da mesma forma:

trans-unit.id: As the photon approaches, its wavelength is shortened in front of it. If it’s originally a yellow photon, then it’s colour turns to blue. We call that a blueshift. If the photon is going away, then that’s the other way around, the wavelength becomes longer. For our yellow photon, its colour turns to red. It’s a redshift! So the Doppler effect gives information about the speed of what we are observing. For example, you can see if a star if moving away from us or if it’s coming in our direction, and we can know at what speed it moves. It’s very useful because knowing the kinematic of the object you are observing allow you to try to reproduce it’s behaviour with computer programs, it’s called modelling. Once you have reproduce a computer model that fits a lot of observation, you can apply it to predict other observations, or guess what’s going to happen to your source in a billion years. For example, with a 3m telescope, you can observe the hydrogen emission line at 21cm. Pointing it to the Milky Way will give you a spectrum, which in that case is the density of hydrogen with respect to its velocity. If along your line of sight you intercepted two spiral arms of the Milky Way moving at a different speed, your spectrum will have two peaks, each at the velocity of its respective arm. So, with radio observation, I can reconstruct the spiral arms of the Milky Way. How cool is that?!
trans-unit.source: As the photon approaches, its wavelength is shortened in front of it. If it’s originally a yellow photon, then it’s colour turns to blue. We call that a blueshift. If the photon is going away, then that’s the other way around, the wavelength becomes longer. For our yellow photon, its colour turns to red. It’s a redshift! So the Doppler effect gives information about the speed of what we are observing. For example, you can see if a star if moving away from us or if it’s coming in our direction, and we can know at what speed it moves. It’s very useful because knowing the kinematic of the object you are observing allow you to try to reproduce it’s behaviour with computer programs, it’s called modelling. Once you have reproduce a computer model that fits a lot of observation, you can apply it to predict other observations, or guess what’s going to happen to your source in a billion years. For example, with a 3m telescope, you can observe the hydrogen emission line at 21cm. Pointing it to the Milky Way will give you a spectrum, which in that case is the density of hydrogen with respect to its velocity. If along your line of sight you intercepted two spiral arms of the Milky Way moving at a different speed, your spectrum will have two peaks, each at the velocity of its respective arm. So, with radio observation, I can reconstruct the spiral arms of the Milky Way. How cool is that?!
trans-unit.target: À medida que um fotão se aproxima, o seu comprimento de onda fica mais curto. Se for originalmente um fotão amarelo, então a sua cor torna-se azul. Chamamos a isto um desvio para o azul. Se o fotão estiver a afastar-se de nós, então é ao contrário, o seu comprimento de onda torna-se maior. O nosso fotão amarelo, torna-se então vermelho - é um desvio para o vermelho! O efeito de Doppler dá-nos informação sobre a velocidade do que estamos a observar. Por exemplo, podemos ver se uma estrela se está a afastar de nós ou se está a aproximar de nós, e podemos saber a que velocidade se está a mover. É muito útil pois sabendo a cinemática de um objeto, podemos tentar reproduzir o seu comportamento com programas de computador - criam-se assim os modelos. Quando conseguimos reproduzir o comportamento observado, podemos aplicar o modelo para prever outras observações, ou para saber o que vai acontecer daqui a mil milhões d eanos. Por exemplo, com um telescópio de 3 m, podemos observar a risca de emissão de hidrogénio de 21 cm. Apontando o telescópio para a Via Láctea, obtemos um espetro, que neste caso é a densidade de hidrogénio em função da sua velocidade. Se ao longo da nossa linha de visão interceptarmos dois braços espirais da Via Láctea que se movem a velocidades diferentes, o nosso espetro terá dois picos, cada um na velocidade correspondente de cada braço. Assim, com as observações de rádio podemos reconstruir os braços espirais da Via Láctea! Fixe?!

trans-unit.id: You want to do that too? Well, you can. Connect to http://www.euhou.net (or flash the QR code down below) and pilot a radio telescope yourself. You will be guided through some exercises to reconstruct the spiral arms of the Milky Way, or search for Dark Matter, with the spectra you will obtain yourself. And you can see the results of your commands in real-time on the telescope thanks to a webcam filming it 24h a day.
trans-unit.source: You want to do that too? Well, you can. Connect to http://www.euhou.net (or flash the QR code down below) and pilot a radio telescope yourself. You will be guided through some exercises to reconstruct the spiral arms of the Milky Way, or search for Dark Matter, with the spectra you will obtain yourself. And you can see the results of your commands in real-time on the telescope thanks to a webcam filming it 24h a day.
trans-unit.target: Também querem tentar fazê-lo? Basta ligarem-se a http://www.euhou.net (ou usar o código QR abaixo) e comandarem um radiotelescópio. Também encontrarão aí alguns exercícios que os ajudarão a reconstruir os braços espirais da Via Láctea, ou a procurar a Matéria Escura, com os espetros que obterão por vós mesmos!.E podem ver o efeito dos vossos comandos no telescópio, em tempo real, através de uma webcam que filma 24 h por dia.

trans-unit.id: I just published a paper called A Dynamical Theory of the Electromagnetic field. I explain how electromagnetic radiations (like light, for example) exist at any wavelengths!
trans-unit.source: I just published a paper called A Dynamical Theory of the Electromagnetic field. I explain how electromagnetic radiations (like light, for example) exist at any wavelengths!
trans-unit.target: Acabei de publicar um artigo intitulado "Uma Teoria Dinâmica do Campo Eletromagnético". Nele, explico como a radiação eletromagnética (como, por exemplo, a luz) pode existir em qualquer comprimento de onda!

trans-unit.source: Thomas Alva Edison If so, then celestial objects must emit some radio waves too…

trans-unit.id: Max Planck Well, according to my calculations, if we consider that the Sun is a Black Body, its radio emission should be very weak. For the moment I think it is not possible to detect it, even with our best instruments.
trans-unit.source: Max Planck Well, according to my calculations, if we consider that the Sun is a Black Body, its radio emission should be very weak. For the moment I think it is not possible to detect it, even with our best instruments.
trans-unit.target: Max Planck Bem, segundo os meus cálculos, se considerarmos que o Sol é um corpo negro, a sua emissão de rádio deve ser muito fraca. Por agora, penso que nem com os nossos melhores instrumentos conseguimos detetá-la.

trans-unit.id: Charles Nordmann I think you are right Max, I put an antenna on the Mont Blanc (in France), but I didn’t detect anything.
trans-unit.source: Charles Nordmann I think you are right Max, I put an antenna on the Mont Blanc (in France), but I didn’t detect anything.
trans-unit.target: Charles Nordmann Penso que tem razão, Max. Coloquei uma antena no Monte Branco (França), mas não consegui observar nada.

trans-unit.id: Unbelievable! It was a normal day at the Bell telephone company, I was working on my radio antenna to establish transatlantic telephone communications (at 14.5 m wavelength), when I suddenly realise that I was picking up a periodic signal from the sky every day. After further investigations, it turns out to be the radio emission of the centre of the Milky Way, our Galaxy!
trans-unit.source: Unbelievable! It was a normal day at the Bell telephone company, I was working on my radio antenna to establish transatlantic telephone communications (at 14.5 m wavelength), when I suddenly realise that I was picking up a periodic signal from the sky every day. After further investigations, it turns out to be the radio emission of the centre of the Milky Way, our Galaxy!
trans-unit.target: Inacreditável! Era um dia normal na companhia de telefones da Bell e eu estava a trabalhar na minha radioantena para estabelecer um comunicação transatlântica por telefone (no comprimento de onda dos 14,5 m). De repente, apercebi-me que estava a apanhar um sinal periódico vindo do céu, todos os dias. Depois de alguma investigação, concluímos que estávamos a observar a emissão rádio do centro da Via Láctea, a nossa Galáxia!

trans-unit.id: James Stanley Hey Same thing happened to us. We are working with the military to build anti-aircraft radars. Every time we point the radars to the Sun, something is jamming them. I think the Sun is emitting meter wave radiations.
trans-unit.source: James Stanley Hey Same thing happened to us. We are working with the military to build anti-aircraft radars. Every time we point the radars to the Sun, something is jamming them. I think the Sun is emitting meter wave radiations.
trans-unit.target: James Stanley Ah! O mesmo aconteceu connosco. Estamos a trabalhar com os militares na construção de radares anti-aéreos. Sempre que aponto os radares para o Sol, qualquer coisa os confunde. Penso que o Sol está a emitir radiação nos comprimentos de onda do metro.

trans-unit.id: Martin Ryle and Antony Hewish Thank you Karl! Owing to your great discovery, we used the Cambridge Interferometer to map the radio sky. We detected a lot of radio sources!
trans-unit.source: Martin Ryle and Antony Hewish Thank you Karl! Owing to your great discovery, we used the Cambridge Interferometer to map the radio sky. We detected a lot of radio sources!
trans-unit.target: Martin Ryle e Antony Hewish Muito obrigado Karl! Devido à sua grande descoberta, usamos o Interferómetro de Cambridge para mapear o céu no rádio. Detetámos muitas fontes de rádio!

trans-unit.id: Grote Reber, John Kraus like this.
trans-unit.source: Grote Reber, John Kraus like this.
trans-unit.target: Grote Reber, John Kraus gostam disto.

trans-unit.id: My supervisor, the famous Jan Oort, asked me to find atomic lines in the radio domain. I found an interesting one: it is the hyperfine transition of neutral hydrogen. If my calculations are correct, this line should be at a wavelength of 21 cm. It should be a weak emission, but, hey, hydrogen is the most abundant atom in the Universe. Why not trying to observe it?
trans-unit.source: My supervisor, the famous Jan Oort, asked me to find atomic lines in the radio domain. I found an interesting one: it is the hyperfine transition of neutral hydrogen. If my calculations are correct, this line should be at a wavelength of 21 cm. It should be a weak emission, but, hey, hydrogen is the most abundant atom in the Universe. Why not trying to observe it?
trans-unit.target: O meu orientador, o famoso Jan Oort, pediu-me para descobrir riscas atómicas no domínio do rádio. Encontrei uma muito interessante: é a transição suprefina do hidrogéio neutro. Se os meus cálculos estiverem corretos, esta risca deve ser no comprimento de onda dos 21 cm. Deve ser uma emissão fraca, mas atenção, o hidrogénio é o átomo mais abundante no Universo. Porque não tentar observá-lo?

trans-unit.id: Edward Mills Purcell and Harold Irving Ewen You are right! We built a 1 m x 1 m horn antenna and we detected the 21 cm line! Think about all the implication for radio astronomy! At 21cm the radiation from neutral hydrogen penetrates much farther than visible light, and it is the most abundant atom in the Universe! That means that we can observe large structures, like other galaxies, very far away.
trans-unit.source: Edward Mills Purcell and Harold Irving Ewen You are right! We built a 1 m x 1 m horn antenna and we detected the 21 cm line! Think about all the implication for radio astronomy! At 21cm the radiation from neutral hydrogen penetrates much farther than visible light, and it is the most abundant atom in the Universe! That means that we can observe large structures, like other galaxies, very far away.
trans-unit.target: Edward Mills Purcell e Harold Irving Ewen Têm razão! Construímos uma antena corneta e detetamos a risca de 21 cm. Pensem nas implicações que terá para a radioastronomia! Nos 21 cm, a radiação do hidrogénio neutro penetra muito mais longe que a luz visível e é o átomo mais abundante no Universo! Quer dizer que vamos conseguir observar as grandes estruturas, como outras galáxias, muito longínquas!

trans-unit.id: Write a comment…
trans-unit.source: Write a comment…
trans-unit.target: Escreva um comentário...

trans-unit.id: We think we just found something very interesting for radio astronomy. We are working at the Bell Telephone Company, and we built an antenna that was originally used to communicate with satellites Echo and Telstar 1 (the first telecommunication satellites ever launched). We accidentally discovered an additional noise of unknown origin during observations on the wavelength 7.35 cm. This noise corresponds to a sky temperature of 2.7 K. And it fills the entire sky almost uniformly! We think that we detected the Cosmic Microwave Background predicted by the Big Bang theory.
trans-unit.source: We think we just found something very interesting for radio astronomy. We are working at the Bell Telephone Company, and we built an antenna that was originally used to communicate with satellites Echo and Telstar 1 (the first telecommunication satellites ever launched). We accidentally discovered an additional noise of unknown origin during observations on the wavelength 7.35 cm. This noise corresponds to a sky temperature of 2.7 K. And it fills the entire sky almost uniformly! We think that we detected the Cosmic Microwave Background predicted by the Big Bang theory.
trans-unit.target: Pensamos que descobrimos algo muito interessante para a radioastronomia. Estamos a trabalhar na Companhia de Telefones Bell e construímos uma antena que era originalmente usada para a comunicação com os satélites Echo e Telstar 1 (os primeiros satélites de telecomunicações alguma vez lançados). Descobrimos acidentalmente um ruído adicional, de origem desconhecida, durante as observações no comprimento de onda dos 7,35 cm. Este ruído corresponde à temperatura do céu de 2,7 K. E preenche todo o céu, praticamente de forma uniforme! Pensamos que detetámos a Radiação Cósmica de Fundo em Micro-ondas, prevista pela teoria do Big Bang.

trans-unit.id: Robert Henry Dicke Well boys, we’ve been scooped…
trans-unit.source: Robert Henry Dicke Well boys, we’ve been scooped…
trans-unit.target: Robert Henry Dicke Bem, rapazes, fomos derrotados...

trans-unit.id: Our project currently includes 11 countries: Germany, Belgium, Cyprus, Spain, France, Greece, Poland, Portugal, Sweden, Romania, UK, and is sustaining a growing community of teachers and educators since 2004.
trans-unit.source: Our project currently includes 11 countries: Germany, Belgium, Cyprus, Spain, France, Greece, Poland, Portugal, Sweden, Romania, UK, and is sustaining a growing community of teachers and educators since 2004.
